context.text: [6], [7], [8] In addition, the SI current-mode circuits have the features of a small delay time in the summation circuit and of constant power consumption, which is independent of an operation frequency.
Figure 4 shows a conventional current attenuator with a high-swing cascode current mirror that reduces the channel-length modulation effect [6], [7].
Moreover, in the high-swing cascode current-mirror structure, the difference between \$\lambda_{1}V_{Ds}\$, and \$\lambda_{2}V_{DS2}\$ can be neglected [6], [7].
In the proposed current attenuator, the scale accuracy is limited by the AC gain error from the current mirrors [6], [7], [8].

references.text: T.S. Fiez, G Liang and D.J. Allstot, "Switched-Current Circuit Design Issues", IEEE J. Solid-State Circuits, vol. 26, no. 3, pp. 192-202, March 1991.

context.text: The low power consumption of the FFT LSI is realized with the aid of current-mode analog circuits using switched current (SI) mode. [6], [7], [8] In addition, the SI current-mode circuits have the features of a small delay time in the summation circuit and of constant power consumption, which is independent of an operation frequency.
Figure 4 shows a conventional current attenuator with a high-swing cascode current mirror that reduces the channel-length modulation effect [6], [7].
Moreover, in the high-swing cascode current-mirror structure, the difference between \$\lambda_{1}V_{Ds}\$, and \$\lambda_{2}V_{DS2}\$ can be neglected [6], [7].
In the proposed current attenuator, the scale accuracy is limited by the AC gain error from the current mirrors [6], [7], [8].
Considering that a high-swing cascode current mirror has the theoretical AC gain error of 0.01% [7], the maximum scale accuracy of our attenuator circuit can be −80 dB.

context.text: Note that most of the state-of-the-art image compression encoders [2], [4] use context based entropy coding which make use of the correlation between nearby pixels within the subbands or between subbands.
In this work, the encoding has no use of inter-subband dependencies (e.g. no parent/child contexts), such as in the zerotree based schemes of [4] and [5].
One way to get around the model dilution problem is to quantize contexts implicitly [10], [11] or explicitly [4].

These compression performance can be further improved, if we use better entropy coding as in [4] which use an adaptive model at bit-based algorithm.
Further improvement can be achieve if we make use of the correlation information between inter-subbands as in [4] or 2-D correlation information as in [13].

context.text: In ANC systems, a conventional approach is to use FIR filters as adaptive controllers where the filter coefficients are adjusted according to least mean square (LMS) algorithm to minimize errors between output of the filters and the desired response [1], [3], [7]–[9].
When IIR filter based on LMS algorithm is employed in ANC, the resulting struture/algorithm is referred to as U-Filtered LMS [1], [18].
To account for secondary path effect, a filtered version of LMS, called filteredX LMS, is commonly used in ANC systems[1], [9].

context.text: There is, however, one potential drawback of FX-LMS because it is limited to linear control/filtering problem [4], [5].
Snyder and Tanaka in [4] introduces neural networks based active noise cancellation that is capable of supplanting the commonly used FX-LMS arrangement for certain nonlinear problems.

Bouchard in [5] improved the algorithm proposed in [4] with the aim of obtaining faster convergence speed by using nonlinear recursive-least squares algorithms and/or lower computational loads by using an alternative approach to compute the instantaneous gradient of the cost function.
The present paper builds upon the results presented in [4], [5], [18].
First, we extend the result of [4], [5], [18] by using radial basis function (RBF) neural networks, instead of multilayer feedforward perceptron networks.

Filtered-X approach of the linear recurrent RBF learning is based on the fact that instantaneous quadratic error at time \$n\$ is affected by weight values of the controller neural networks at the last \$L+1\$ samples (weight values at time \$n, n - 1,\ldots ,n-L)\$, where \$L\$ is the number of tapped delay lines before the model neural networks [4], [5], [18].

context.text: There is, however, one potential drawback of FX-LMS because it is limited to linear control/filtering problem [4], [5].

In ANC systems, nonlinear phenomena is commonly originated from nonlinearity of the acoustic system under control, or nonlinearity in the secondary actuator, particularly when it operates with an input signal having an amplitude close to (or above) saturation, or when it operates in a frequency range close to (or lower than) the minimum operating frequency of the actuator [5], [19].

Bouchard in [5] improved the algorithm proposed in [4] with the aim of obtaining faster convergence speed by using nonlinear recursive-least squares algorithms and/or lower computational loads by using an alternative approach to compute the instantaneous gradient of the cost function.
The present paper builds upon the results presented in [4], [5], [18].
First, we extend the result of [4], [5], [18] by using radial basis function (RBF) neural networks, instead of multilayer feedforward perceptron networks.

Filtered-X approach of the linear recurrent RBF learning is based on the fact that instantaneous quadratic error at time \$n\$ is affected by weight values of the controller neural networks at the last \$L+1\$ samples (weight values at time \$n, n - 1,\ldots ,n-L)\$, where \$L\$ is the number of tapped delay lines before the model neural networks [4], [5], [18].

context.text: FPGAs implement logic cells as a Look Up Table (LUT) memory, therefore the inherent way of perfor-ming multiplication seems the LUT based Multiplication (LM) [2], [3] where the value of the coefficient is coded into the contents of the LUT memory.
Therefore a modified conversion algorithm has been proposed in [3], for which a 1 is introduced only when the total number of non-zero symbols is reduced.
Therefore the solution is to split the argument, use LUTs, and then use a tree of adders [2], [3], [4].
For the LM some optimisation can be achieved [3].
In general case, optimal splitting of the input argument is much more complicated [3].

As a result, an exhaustive search algorithm (with some obvious simplifications) has been implemented [3], therefore the BSRs together with the distributed RAMs and adders are combined and the best circuit taken.

context.text: Secondly, the demand of detectors able to efficiently mitigate crosstalk for large scale systems has led to the analysis of reduced-rank detectors, especially multistage detectors [4], [5], [6], [7]–.

In this work we provide an equation to precisely calculate the asymptotic weighting required for the optimality criteria proposed in [4] and in [6] in the case of unequal received powers and also a general equation for the limiting SINR achievable at the filter output, as \$ N\rightarrow\infty\$ and \$\beta\$ is constant, applicable to any multistage detector.

In such a case the difference between the joint minimization of the MSE proposed in [4] and the minimization of the MSE for each user proposed in [6] appears and the maximization of the SINR is achieved only in the second case.

We rewrite the detector for the optimality criterion proposed in [4] as \${\rm L}=\Sigma_{l=0}^{L-1}w_{l}{\rm R}^{l}{\rm A}^{H}{\rm S}^{H}\$ and the detector proposed in [6] as \${\rm M}=\sum_{l=0}^{L-1}{\rm W}_{l}{\rm R}^{l}{\rm A}^{H}{\rm S}^{H}\$ with W being diagonal.
As shown in [4], the true LMMSE detector is in \$\chi_{K}({\bf SA})\$.

The optimum scalar weights \$w_{l}\$ for the jointly LMMSE detector in \$\chi_{L}({\bf SA})\$ are given by [4]
 where the \$L\$-dimensional vector c and the elements of the \$L\times L\$ matrix \$\Phi\$ can be expressed in terms of the traces of the powers of \${\bf R}\$ as \$c_{{i}}= {\rm trace}({\bf R}^{i})\$ and \$\Phi_{ij}= {\rm trace} ({\bf R}^{i+j})+\sigma^{2} {\rm trace} ({\bf R}^{i+j-1})\$.

For \$L\geq K\$ the equality is due to the fact that the jointly LMMSE detector and then, obviously, also the individually LMMSE detector in \$\chi_{L} ({\bf SA})\$ coincide with the true LMMSE [4] and, as well known, the latter maximizes jointly the \${\rm MSINR}_{i}\$ for all the users.

context.text: Secondly, the demand of detectors able to efficiently mitigate crosstalk for large scale systems has led to the analysis of reduced-rank detectors, especially multistage detectors [4], [5], [6], [7]–.
As shown in [5], [6], for this class of detectors, a low number of stages is sufficient for near-LMMSE (linear minimum-mean square error) performance, even as system size grows large.
However, asymptotic weighting is unknown for unequal received powers and performance has been analyzed only for the optimality criterion proposed in [6].

In this work we provide an equation to precisely calculate the asymptotic weighting required for the optimality criteria proposed in [4] and in [6] in the case of unequal received powers and also a general equation for the limiting SINR achievable at the filter output, as \$ N\rightarrow\infty\$ and \$\beta\$ is constant, applicable to any multistage detector.

In such a case the difference between the joint minimization of the MSE proposed in [4] and the minimization of the MSE for each user proposed in [6] appears and the maximization of the SINR is achieved only in the second case.

We rewrite the detector for the optimality criterion proposed in [4] as \${\rm L}=\Sigma_{l=0}^{L-1}w_{l}{\rm R}^{l}{\rm A}^{H}{\rm S}^{H}\$ and the detector proposed in [6] as \${\rm M}=\sum_{l=0}^{L-1}{\rm W}_{l}{\rm R}^{l}{\rm A}^{H}{\rm S}^{H}\$ with W being diagonal.

A recursive structure of the individually LMMSE detector in \$\chi_{L} ({\bf SA})\$ is provided in [6] 11In [6] the individually LMMSE detector in \$\chi_{L}({\bf SA})\$ is referred to as MultiStage Wiener Filter. and it is equivalent to the following: where2\$({\rm w}_{i})_{l}=({\rm W}_{l})_{ii}=w_{il}, ({\rm c}_{i})_{l}=({\bf R}^{l+1})_{ii}\$ and \$(\Phi_{i})_{im}=({\bf R}^{l+m})_{ii}+\sigma^{2}({\bf R}^{t+m-1})_{ii}\$.
In [6] the individually LMMSE detector in \$\chi_{L}({\bf SA})\$ is referred to as MultiStage Wiener Filter.

 with modified scaline parameter \$E_{b,r0}=C^{-(\alpha+\beta)}\cdot(a+b/a)^{1/(\alpha+\beta)}\cdot\dot E^{\alpha/(\alpha+\beta)}\$[22].
However, extrapolation anticipates the shape parameters being constant for the full time and size range; this condition is in fact somewhat in question [22].
Weibull-like functions such as the Gom-pertz function, and also a sum of two-parameter Weibull distribution functions, give more satisfying fits to non-boiling LHe breakdown data [22].
A threshold has also been claimed for LHe breakdown by statistical arguments [22], see for instance Figure 11.
The interference of area and volume effect, respectively, depends on the actual gap conditions and cannot be specified a priori [22], [25], [27].
Coincidence with Weibull shape parameters, although claimed to be matching for distinct sample arrangements, may be poor in general [22], [29].
The breakdown data are fitted to a sum of two-parameter Weibull distribution functions; the lower distribution trace representing the particle impact [22].
A low breakdown limit of more than 10 kVrnm –1 is quite evident [22].
